transcripts.text: Order!  Order!  You are an incorrigible delinquent at times.
Save yourself, man!

You claim people are making unrealistic assumptions on the other side of the argument, though not all the assumptions you listed are made by everybody.  Some of them were in the Treasury report, others didn't make these assumptions.  But it's a fair assumption if we leave.  that whatever our relationship is with the EU, and of course we will continue to have a trading relationship, I don't think anybody could deny that, but it will not be as open, it will not give us the same open, untrammeled access that we have now.  That's a fair assumption, isn't it?

No, I absolutely don't agree.  You know, the fact is we are unique in the world, having an economy that is totally aligned for the last 43 years.  All our rules, the contents of a sausage, all the rest of it is aligned to that of the EU.  We currently trade tariff-free, so it will be very easy, and even more in their interest than in ours, to continue to trade tariff-free.

So let me get this right.  You're claiming... That we could leave the EU, which will mean, because you've made a big song and dance about it, ending free movement of peoples.  That would not apply to the United Kingdom.  But we would still access the single market on the same basis as we do now?
We would continue to trade tariff-free because it's in their interests even more than ours.  And just to be clear...
No, let me try and get you to be clear, because it's interesting.  On the same basis as now?  We would trade on the same basis, is your claim?

It will be absolutely in their interests, even more than ours.  We have a big deficit with the European Union.  And let's be clear, the EU has some modest free trade agreements with the rest of the world, not nearly as many as Switzerland, but they do have some free trade agreements.  Those countries trade tariff-free with the EU and they do not have free movement of labour.  So to suggest that the only way to access the European market tariff-free is with free movement is simply not true, Andrew.
But if... Europe was to agree that there would be no price of membership for being part of the single market.  There's no free movement.
We won't be part of the single market.
No, but you're saying we'd have the same access as if we were.
No.
Well, I asked you if it was on the same terms.
No.  The single market has become a big totemic issue.  We do not want to be in the single market.  We want to trade tariff-free with the European Union.
But in terms of trade, we'd have the same access as we do now?
I believe we will trade tariff-free.

So, if the European Union conceded that to us... What would stop Sweden, Denmark, Poland, other countries saying, we'll have that too?  then, if the Brits get that?  The European Union elite is never going to agree to that, you know that.
Well, you know, the point is, it's not up to the European elite.  We hear so much about the European...
It is when it comes to negotiations.

No, it's not.  Businesses do business with businesses.  We do more trade with the United States than almost anyone else.  We don't even have a free trade agreement with them.  You don't actually need a free trade agreement to do business.
Businesses are telling us not to leave the EU.  No, they're not.
Dyson, JCB are telling us to leave.  No, the bulk of SMEs, small and medium businesses, are telling us to leave.

So it's not the bulk.  Well, it is the bulk of big businesses.  The bulk of big businesses are telling Britain to stay in the European Union.  Big businesses, yes.  That's what I said.  And we're proposing to, or you're proposing, that we should ignore that.  What makes you think that if your advice is to ignore that, it will not be the... advice of other European countries, they should ignore big business too.

So let's talk about this.  Jamie Dimon of JP Morgan says we should stay in the EU.  JP Morgan have been fined $8 billion for their deliberate part in creating the financial crisis that brought the world to its knees.  Can they speak for the poor people, for the workers in this country?

You've claimed and this is my final question, that your colleagues, if we leave, we can design rules, talking again about access rules, single market rules, that suit the British economy, not the requirements of Latvia or Spain.  What Latvian requirements have we had to meet?
What I'm saying is that because we have a big trade deficit with Europe, because they sell more to us than we do to them, they will need to continue to access the UK market.

No, but that's not what I'm asking you.  Your people are saying that we have to meet the requirements of Latvia or Spain.  So let me widen it to both.  What requirements from Latvia and Spain have we been forced to meet?

The UK is subject, 60% of all our rules and regulations come from the European Union.  There are all manner of regulations about things like the live export of animals, about things like VAT on fuel bills.  OK.
But we're forced to impose those as a result of EU membership.  But you can't name me a requirement from Latvia, Spain, that we've had to adopt.
Well, because they're made under 28 EU member states, aren't they, by the European Commission?
All right.  We'll leave it there.  I've been getting away with it all my life.  Getting away.
